Entry.1:
We arrived at marseilles today at eleven am after 5½ days sail from Alexandria & having arrived at marseilles all preparations were made for disembarking that afternoon about 3pm we left the wharf and marched through the town on to the railway Station we all got aboard there train there and about 5.30pm. the train moved out on a 3 day journey to the north of france. the people were all allong the railways waving and by all appearances glad to see us This is where I seen the first German prisoners They were working on the wharf under

​

an armed guard.our Boyshooted them when they seen them. They looked as if they did not mind being in the care of the francs.

Entry.19:

Fricourt farm

We were supposed to move to Bapaume this morning but the move order was cancelled at the last moment We are moving tomorrow at 9 AM not being much doing around this place just now altho this morning and last night there has been a heavy bombardment going on The huns were supposed to have made three counter attacks on the British troops last night all were repelled with severe losses to the enemy Joe has gone to this afternoon to have a look at the

and back again to the muddy Somme once more am I sorry that I am on my return journey yes I am but it is over there where duty lies and we must go my trip to Ireland I shall never forget for many a day to come Every

Entry.47:
1916
on Board train Bound for amiens

at 6 this morning we left the Docks RestCamp and marched to Havre Railway Station through a heavy downpour of rain needless for me to say that we received a drenching. I am writing this in the train at some wayside Station and it is still Raining I have just come to the conclusion that this country was made for Ducks to live in not men. Well my trip to the old country is now at an End. But it is one that I will always be able to look back with the fondest memories I was in England Scotland and lastly But the best of all was Ireland. Some day if god Spares me, I will go again



we are due in Amiens some time tomorrow morning I should say about 7 am Wrote a pc to Minnie yesterday but cannot post it until I return to the Battalion But met Jordan at havre last night he goes to Blighty tonight with 9 others of the
Entry.48:
Battn

Night time
have been travelling all day in the train and its raining like one thing Since tuesday night I have been on my way back Tuesday night I left Larne Harbour in Ireland and went to Stranraer by boat from there I caught the train forLondon via Scotland arrived there at 10.30 wednesday morning stopped that day in London and left waterloo station at 4 pm

On Thursday afternoon arrived at Southampton 7:30 went on board Ship again and across the English Channel to havre where we landed on Friday morning at 8 Stayed in the RestCamp at caught the train at 6.30 this morning we will arrive sometime in theearly morning at Amiens where we will join up with the Battalion.

31 12 16

arrived home at 12pm today from Blighty arrived at amiens at 2AM and rested in the YMCA until 8pm and then we met geo Smith and they showed us the way home it is raining here tonight

and no doubt tomorrow New year sports will be postponed we are leaving here on Tuesday for Ribemont and back into the trenches once more Wrote to Auntieand Cousin Harry to night
Entry.49:
Coisy

Oh oh what a rotten possie we are in Coisy is its name But cannot say that it is what one would call Cosy. Since I have been away to Ireland the sick parades have deminished a lot When I left they used to be 100 strong now they are not more than 30 strong Joe goes away to Ireland on leave tonight and hopethat he has a time like I had and that



one of the best times that I have hadsince leaving australia in 1914. Tomorrow we are going to march to Ribemont Distance 15 miles we are on our way back to the firing line which is on the Somme In a few months time from now the allies are going to smash thegermans to atoms We will have more guns and ammunition than ever we had and best of all we are going to havea million fresh

troops oh Kaiser will need to look to your laurels in the near future for a certain we are going to crush you and your army in the spring and the war will end before next xmas that is the belief of every allied soldier today

Entry.53:
Ribemont
I went to Heilly this morning and again this afternoon for water the reason why I made 2 trips was that tomorrow morning we are leaving Ribemont for Mametz wood which is about 9 miles from here. and the water will be needed on the march up. We are to relieve in the line for 6 weeks. then we come out and go up north again. I suppose it will be somewhere about Ypres or Bois Grenier again when we left those positions some months ago things were very quiet have not received any news

from Minnie yet. No doubt one ought to come along shortly it rained here last night so you can bet the roads are very muddy they must be terrible up the line. By this time nothing more to mention for today Thomas has not arrived yet I do not know what can be delaying him at all he is 9 days he may reach home tomorrow sometime lets hope so at all events

Au Re Voir
Entry.54:
Mametz Wood

We have just landed at the above wood which is about miles from Ribemont We left Ribemont at 8 this morning and reached here about 1 pm the roads are very muddy indeed I have received orders that I am to go to Quarries Siding in the morning with A and D Company They are going up on fatigue duty
Entry.55:
Quarries Siding

left Mametz Wood this morning at 7-20 this morning for the above Siding Coming up the roads indeed there is one thing certain and that is none of us will be sorrywhen the Summer comes along again We are in Huts I am with the Sergeants but I would rather be amongst the men

Au Re Voir

Entry.67:

made 2 trips to flers today with waterthe huns - left us alone pretty welltoday he was shelling moreto the right. have had only one man wounded in the Battalion since they went to flers. is not home after our Guns have been Straffing the huns this morning
Entry.68:
Bernafay Wood

went to flers today during last night the 29th English Div attacked the germans They were very successful as they captured 500 prisoners I seen them marching in this morning and they did not look to bad at all the 15th Btn also made an attack last night and captured 2 lines of trenches The 29th Division was the gallant Englishmen that made the landing at Cape Helles at the dardenelles on the 25th April 1915 it

is no better Division in the British army Than the 29th.
Entry.69:
Bernafay Wood

I delivered 4 carts of water today at flers Nothing happened This morning Fritzy kept pretty quiet but coming home this afternoon just as we reached Longueval Corner Fritzy shot a Big Shell just on the corner That place was too unhealthy for me so I beckoned to the driver to hurry which he did We had just passed the corner when I heard another one coming and I took cover Behind a motor lorry

as. Soon as I did the Shells hit the side of the Road not more than six yards away from where I was. Indeed I was lucky to get away unhurt - it missed the water carts by inches we will get another of these receptions shortly Seen 3 German aeroplanes brought down yesterday the artillery was very active today in front of the 14th armys positions they are progressing well and I believe they are makeing for Transloy. Rumors go that they are closer than half way from the English front 110 on the

Entry.75:
Bernafay Wd

a couple of german aeroplanes came over our Camp this morning but after a few shots from our anti air craft guns they pushed home The germans fly very high and are very hard to hit I am sure their observation cannot be very good from such a height artillary duels going on about flers the 15th Batt attacked a german strong point on the first and capturedit but were blown out later They captured prisoners Seen 2 germans this mormning with the Iron Cross





I would have liked to have stolen one of them but there was an English officer with them so my chances of success was small indeed

today has been rather a busy one water had to be sent to the trenches after that was done we had to pack up and change our camp from Bernafay wood to the Quarry The 13th Battalion are going to make an attack tonight in conjunction with various other Battalions no doubt the 13 will make good
